awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Dynamics and Control of Long Range Micro Air Vehicles Inspired by Monarch Butterflies
awd_abstract_narration:
This Collaborative research project will study the biomechanics of Monarch butterfly flight, with the goal of creating engineered flight vehicles with unprecedented capabilities. The seemingly fragile Monarch exhibits the longest flight range among insects. Individual Monarch butterflies may travel up to four thousand kilometers during the annual migration between North America and Central America. This project will examine the distinguishing characteristics of Monarch butterfly flight, including the slow tempo of the flapping wings, the effects of wing flexibility, and the mechanical coupling of wing and body movements. Furthermore, the Monarch flies at relatively high altitudes. Glider pilots have observed Monarch butterflies soaring on thermal currents at altitudes up to 1,250 km, and their overwintering grounds are at altitudes of up to 3,300 km. This project will examine whether the unmatched range of the Monarch among similarly sized animals lies in the combination of large, flexible wings, slow flapping speeds, and high-altitude flight. A multidisciplinary team will integrate expertise in computational mechanics, biological experiments, fluid dynamics, and nonlinear controls to uncover the physical mechanism underlying the highly efficient Monarch flight. This knowledge will be applied to the creation of transformative, bio-inspired micro-air vehicles with enhanced flight efficiency and superior flight range. Micro-air vehicles with extended flight range will improve the national quality of life by enabling long-term monitoring of environmental hazards. These vehicles will enhance national security by allowing long-term surveillance of large areas, and by providing long-range reconnoitering capacity for search and rescue. Engineering models of Monarch flight will also contribute to the understanding of their migration patterns, and thereby support the conservation of this endangered species.

The primary scientific objective of this project is to test the hypothesis that high-altitude flight is a critical component to the long-range flight characteristics of the Monarch butterfly. This will be achieved with a series of experimental, computational, and theoretical research efforts. The flight maneuvers of live Monarch will be measured by a motion capture system in a low-pressure chamber simulating the ambient environment at various altitudes. The measurements will be validated with computational fluid dynamics simulations for the unsteady viscous flows around flexible flapping wings integrated with a multibody dynamics model representing the thorax and the abdomen deformation. The resulting aerodynamic model will be approximated by an artificial neural network for real-time dynamic simulation, from which a nonlinear feedback control system will be constructed via Floquet-Lypuanov theory. The fidelity of the computational dynamic model and the feedback control system will be verified against experiments with Monarch butterfly inspired micro-air vehicle and live butterfly flight measurements. These will provide a comprehensive analysis of the low-frequency flapping dynamics of an articulated, flexible multibody system representing the remarkable flight characteristics of Monarch butterflies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative research project studied the biomechanics of Monarch butterfly flight. The seemingly fragile Monarch exhibits one of the longest flight ranges among insects. Individual Monarch butterflies may travel up to four thousand kilometers during the annual migration between North America and Central America. This project provides foundations and knowledge from which transformative, bio-inspired micro-air vehicles with enhanced flight efficiency and superior flight range can be designed and developed. Micro-air vehicles with extended flight range will improve the national quality of life by enabling long-term monitoring of environmental hazards. These vehicles will enhance national security by allowing long-term surveillance of large areas, and by providing long-range reconnoitering capacity for search and rescue. Engineering models of Monarch flight will also contribute to the understanding of their migration patterns, and thereby support the conservation of this endangered species.

The project tested the hypothesis that Monarchs generate higher lift coefficients at higher altitudes using a series of experimental, computational, and theoretical research efforts. The Monarch flies at relatively high altitudes. Glider pilots have observed Monarch butterflies soaring on thermal currents at altitudes up to 1,250 m, and their overwintering grounds are at altitudes of up to 3,300 m. At these altitudes, the air density is lower than at sea level. Free flight observations of Monarch butterflies in a vacuum chamber, simulating higher altitudes by reducing air densities, support this hypothesis (Fig. 1). In addition, computational fluid dynamics simulations of flexible wings at the Monarch scale show that the power consumption reduces with the altitude, implying that the Monarchs' flights are more efficient at higher altitudes (Fig. 1). Further analysis of these results demonstrates that both are outcomes of the interplay with the flexible wing motion and the body dynamics. These results suggest that bioinspired micro flying robots can benefit from using flexible wing structures. Not only can the power consumption be much lower with a more flexible wing, the resulting force generation and power consumption can also be modulated by changing the wing stiffness or the flight altitude. This novel understanding of the fluid-structure interaction of butterfly-inspired flexible wings can help designing next-generation highly efficient long-range drones. 

This project has led to broader impacts within and beyond engineering. The optical measurement system was utilized to enable gait measurement in underwater treadmills. This could improve the effectiveness of the exercise routines by clinicians and physical therapists in clinical rehabilitation programs. The physical mechanism behind the bioinspired wing motion and flexible wing dynamics was applied to develop a novel Martian flight vehicle concept. Martian aerial exploration could enable a wide range of new Mars missions. The project has provided research, training, and international collaboration opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students. The research outcomes were also integrated into a cross-curricular educational project called Monarch Madness in collaboration with Title I elementary schools in northern Alabama, where a significant portion is from underrepresented groups.
